author: peter.davies
content: <@!441484183852810240> I believe you are correct that the yellow paper is inconsistent as to which way round the two values are returned by the `PoW` function. This sort of mistake tends to be missed by human reader, much like number theorists forget to specify that `p` is prime.

author: peter.davies
content: Personally, I think the clash of notation between the `H_n` and `n` is more egregious. It results in a very confusing appearance of `(x, m) = PoW(...)` in equation 170 on page 14 for disambiguation reasons.

author: gb429
content: <@!243183686562873344> I completely understand... I wouldn't have raised such a trivial issue had I come across the second use of the formula before posting it. And I agree with your second point - I went back and read the equations 168-171 again and it seems like n _is the block header nounce_. These 4 equations also use B instead of H to denote the block headers, which made a little more confusing for me as B is used to refer to the whole block in previous paragraphs (equation 19 on page 5).

author: peter.davies
content: Indeed there are two `n`'s, the random nonce you put differently into the PoW function on each attempt and the `n` that tells you how good quality your proof of work attempt is.
